Thanks for that Derek.  Personally, I try to have the average specie
size to be about 10, which allows for sorting and the mating of the
top n%, either by tuning the threshold manually or choosing the
required number of species for dynamic threshold manipulation.

I haven't clamped my species, to be honest, never even thought of it
as an option.

I have thought about having an average specie size of around 30 as
this is supposed to be the min size of a cow herd, for example, to
have enough genetic material to produce healty offspring.  Not so sure
 it matters so much here if brother and sister mate though.

Also, I seem to remember 30 being the smallest statistically
significant size for a sample, so maybe we should always aim for that
number of species.

Ken, any thoughts/opinions as to specie number clamping or specie size
etc.

Cheers

Matt

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> Hi Matt,
> 
> I think to a certain extent it's dependent on your population size. 
> Larger populations are more tolerant of more species.
> 
> I think most of the current NEAT implementations clamp the number of
> species...something like 5-8 (please correct me if I'm wrong on this).
>  Obviously if you only have 1 species, you're not exploiting its
> advantages...likewise if you have a population of 100 and you have 100
> species (everyone is in their own species), you're not getting any
> crossover.
> 
> ANJI doesn't clamp the number of species, and so we end up tuning the
> threshold manually.  We usually end up with somewhere between 20-30
> species in a typical run.
> 
> Theoretically, I like to think of species as camps moving out into the
> search space and exploring.  They're clusters of similar solutions in
> the fitness landscape.  You don't want too many and you don't want too
> few.  And you want a certain amount of turnover or dynamism, because
> you want to encourage more exploration, and probably have some search
> spaces abandoned in favor of more promising ones.
> 
> Others may have some insights into why they clamped the species size.
> 
> The short answer, though not very helpful, is somewhere between 1 and
> your population size. :)
> 
> Derek
> 
> On 9/7/05, Matt Simmerson <m.simmerson@b...> wrote:
> > Hi

> > Just wondering if anyone has any view as to the optimum(ish) number of
> > species.  My implementation will cope with both a fixed and dynamic
> > compatability threshold so I can control the number of species to a
> > certain degree.
> > 
> > I find that with a fixed CT, the number of species decline eventually
> > to just a few, after intially having many (tens/hundreds).
> > 
> > Thoughts, opinoins etc very much welcomed.
